answers.author: Mike Cohen
answers.text:
Nickie,
Peak Democracy has worked with dozens of local governments to establish what you call "e-town hall meetings" -- and many of these online forums have been focused on citizen feedback on budgets. These online forums typically get 3 to over 10 times the amount of citizen participation from conventional public hearings. Also, the forums can be easily integrated with local government social media (i.e. Facebook and Twitter). I appended below links to a variety of examples. If you want to further explore a collaboration, then contact me and/or go to http://www.PeakDemocracy.com.
Regards, 
Mike

answers.author: Tom Nosack
answers.text:
We did a cool, low cost outreach about a year and a half ago using a live group that we televised over our cable TV and streaming on the net. We set it up to allow others to participate via smart phone or home computer. We announced it ahead of time in the newspaper and on our web site.
The live group answered a set of questions using handheld polling devices (we had purchased from Turning Technologies) while at the same time those who were watching answered the same questions using a widget on their smart phone or by signing in with a computer. 
The software for the polling devices automatically added up the responses and showed it in our PowerPoint live; the software that allowed remote users was also pretty easy to operate and was “rentable” for a single use by the same company that sells the polling devices. Their responses were added to the in room ones for a very powerful message! We had about 40 in the room and about another 30 participate remotely. It was a big hit, and got good press.  - Tom

answers.author: Pooja Varma
answers.text:
Hi Nickie,
You may want to look at the KN documents section and go through the literature available on civic engagement in Budgeting. A few that may be of interest are:
a)  Tarpon Springs’s Strategic Budgeting Using Public Opinion Polling, where University of South Florida conducted a poll asking residents their opinions on taxes, cutting services etc. and used public hearings in 2002 that informed the City’s financial planning.  http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/100361/Tarpon_Springss_Strategic_Budgeting_Using_Public_Opinion_Polling 
b)  Public Involvement in Budgeting: Options for Local Officials, discusses the improving transparency and communication through public outreach, surveys, budget advisory committees, workshops, and public forms and explains how to use these tools.  http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/1805/Public_Involvement_in_Budgeting_Options_for_Local_Officials 
c)   One City's Success: Citizen Involvement in Financial Planning, illustrates a one year financial study conducted in Huntington Woods, Michigan. A citizen committee was created to enhance participation in short and long term budgeting . The study provides a successful and replicable model for other municipalities.  http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/7329/One_Citys_Success_Citizen_Involvement_in_Financial_Planning 
You may also want to look at the questions under Budgeting and Citizen Engagement. There is one on and “Citizen Meetings/Classes - City Operations” that has a discussion and links on the different programs created to educate citizens on government processes and increasing civic understanding of financial planning that should be useful. 
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/questions/kn/Question/20991/Citizen_MeetingsClasses__City_Operations 
I hope this helps,
Pooja Varma
Knowledge Network Intern 
pvarma@icma.org

answers.author: Katherine Woerner Caffrey
answers.text:
Hi Nickie-
(Congrats on Olathe!) You may want to check out what the City of Austin did last year. They did a neat exercise where residents got to "pick" what to keep and what to get rid of...definitely showed how hard it is to make those tough decisions. Justin Golbabai works in their Budget Office and is a KUCIMAT...you can contact him.
Also City of Round Rock did an exercise a few years ago where they brought residents in to do an exercise where they picked what level of service they wanted (they called the levels Lexus, Camry and Corolla). It was interactive and fun. If you want more info, email me.

author: Nickie Lee
text: We have hosted "traditional" budget input meetings over the past few years with low turnout. We have made presentations at City Hall and traveled to locations thorughout the city, but would like to try something new this year to encourage more citizen involvement. We are looking into hosting an "E Town Hall Meeting", allowing citizens to submit questions about the 2012 budget online via email, social media, etc. Has anyone tried this kind of meeting, and how successful has it been? Any advice as we move ahead? Thanks!
title: Citizen Feedback on the Budget Process
